simplesect.para: At cocktail parties, people no longer give me blank looks when I tell them I write free software. "Oh, yes, Open Source — like Linux and all that stuff?" they say. I nod eagerly in agreement. The terms free software and open source are largely interchangeable, though the latter seems to be in wider use among non-programmers. "Yes, exactly! That's what we work on," I say.
simplesect.remark: (Is <emphasis> the right thing for the terms above? I didn't want to use <firstterm> because the terms aren't actually defined here, just mentioned.)
simplesect.para: Over the last couple of decades, Free Software has gone from being an obscure, mostly unfunded sideline in the software development world, to a [todo]... but, although people now know what it is, they don't know how it works. The most common questions are: "But how do you get paid?" and "Who makes the decisions in these projects?".

sect1.title: Who Should Read This Book?
sect1.para: Describe target audience(s), and assumed reader background. (As in, the reader should know what the terms "source code" and "commit" mean, even if doesn't write code, etc.) Also: explain that to an experienced free software programmer, much of this book will seem obvious, trite, and boring. Point out how wide the gap is and how you don't need the bridge if you're already on the other side.

sect1.title: Terminology
sect1.remark: (I looked at moving Terminology into Chapter 1, as you suggested. The problem is that it would need to come early, since both terms are used in the remainder of the chapter, but I'm pretty happy with the way Chapter 1 currently begins, and it doesn't have a really good place for an early terminology detour. So for now the terminology is here. Not sure what the best solution is... I'm leaning toward leaving it here, but making it as brief as possible, and including pointers to later sections where further detail is warranted.)
sect1.para: Explain very briefly how the two terms FS and OSS are synonymous, though different in emphasis; talk about how people got confused by "free", mention the open source consortium. Point out that the term "open source" gives the useful contrasting term "closed source", which is much more descriptive than "non-free". But this initial mention of FS/OSS terminology should be very short, only a paragraph or so. Leave the rest for the History section in Chapter 1, .

Anamoly: "closed-source" is almost always hyphenated, "open source" is not. Dunno why this is, but at least it should be acknowledged. Also, note how "commercial" is not being used as an antonym for "free / open source" here: plenty of free software projects are commercial in intent. The important difference is proprietary vs non-proprietary, not commercial vs non-commercial.
Explain very briefly the difference between source code and executable code, and why it matters. Or should we just assume that background?

sect2.title: Sourcing Conventions
sect2.para: Might want to note why a URL is sometimes given and sometimes not. Basically, it's a matter of convenience. When offering a quote, for example, it's best to give the actual web page. But a mention of a project may or may not call for a URL, depending on the context. The general principle is that if the obvious Google search would quickly lead to the item in question, then there's no point giving the URL, unless it would be very easy & unobtrusive to do so.
